issue.title: TSC/TSR: the grand fantabulous time series classification and time series regression super mega hyper bake-off

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Bake-off in python toolbox with full set of methods and suite of post-hoc analyses.

Conditional on:
- data loading implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/8
- baseline methods and transformer principles implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/7
- UEA favourite methods implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/10
- grid-tuning implemented https://github.com/kiraly-group/sktime/issues/4

body: obsolete, since decision was made to separate trafo from data container

rename.from: TSC/TSR: interface xpandas trafo/learner pipeline, or replicate

body: for this, check suitability of using sklearn Pipeline method (duck typing)

Few commits with dummy transformers and additional tests have been added to demonstrate that the existing sklearn pipeline can be used with duck typing. Fortunately,
1. Our dummy estimators and dummy transformers work properly with duck typing
2. Both series to features and series to series transformers work properly as demonstrated by the new tests

However,
1. Transforms can only be applied on X. To have transforms on y, we have to extend the existing pipeline functionality with appropriate distinction checks to separately process our transformers and pre-existing sklearn transformers. This is already done in the pipeline implementation of https://github.com/dmbee/seglearn (Another sklearn compatible module for time-series analysis). We can either use seglearn implementations or just adapt from it and avoid dependency.
2. The column transformer available in sklearn that we discussed in the previous meeting is still experimental-level API and couldn't work with series to series transformations. However, this is still useful and we might possibly be able to extend this to support series-to-series transformers.
Regarding 1.: That's I think why the higher level interface is useful - X and y should not be treated separately (as i've suggested initially)
The relevant examples for pipeline usage can be found at https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/dev/sktime/tests/test_pipelines.py

rename.to: TSC/TSR: implement pipeline building functionality with transformers on y

body:
* add `check_input` flag to init to deactivate input checks for all of its components (transformers, final estimator)
* add `random_state` in init to set random seed for all of its components
Separate design/implementation of transformers on y into separate issues #44.
